content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks great

Looks good !
One thing is bothering me :
If you have to replace all 'AA' by 'AT', what should 'AAA' become ? 'ATA' or 'AAT' ?
It should be more explicit.
Secondly, why do you give strand2, which can be find from strand1 ?

I took a while to understand the problem. I would suggest to place first paragraph after the second paragraph. I also like to reword to make it short. Here is the suggested one.

"""
DNA sequence is a double helix consisting of 2 strands. The genetic letters are A, C, G and T (Adenine, Cytosine, Guanine, Thymine). These letters always connect in pairs between the two strands of a double helix. A with T and C with G, which means if you have an A at position x of a strand, then you must have a T at the same position of the opposing strand.

The DNA sequence has to be repaired by <<replacing all occurrences of a bad gene with the good gene>>. The output has to be the repaired DNA sequence.

...
....

"""

Can we remove the following sentence? When you say valid it means DNS sequence is already correct and no repair needed. This confused me.

"The inputs are always valid DNA sequences containing only the four genetic letters A, C, G and T. There are no test cases checking for invalid inputs."

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good, excellent job!

I would suggest removing the invalid inputs, building a contingency to handle those takes long enough that I wouldn't consider this a good fit for the "fastest" clash mode.

For example, ignoring the invalid contingencies my fastest solution was about 2 minutes, but it took another 4 to build an invalid detection system. I understand that others could build one faster, but it just seems like unnecessary complexity to me.

Otherwise, looks pretty good!

The Input calls them strandA and strandB; the Output calls them strand 1 and strand 2.

Tests and Validators 2 and 3 (and even your visualization) have input strands which do not correspond to the A-T and C-G pairs in an area outside the defect gene - e.g., in Test 2, both strings end in 'C'; I understand one of them should end in G. What is to be done with those?
Thanks for your review. You are absolutely right, you have a good eye ;-) I corrected the test cases and replaced the strandA and strandB references with strand1 and strand2.
I thought about exactly that and you just convinced me. I will remove the invalid possibility tomorrow. Thanks for the review.
Thanks, I appreciate it. How about an upvote as well? I still try to unlock that "first contribution" milestone :D

Thank you for your feedback. I like your suggestion and used your shorter/reordered statement. I also removed tha sentence about "valid" sequence; you are right, this can be confusing. Though I left the statement: There are no test cases checking for invalid inputs (i.e. letters other than ACGT)

Thanks for the feedback. You are right, strand2 can be (easily) deduced from strand one, so I thought why not provide it to make the task a little bit simpler.

About your example with "AAA". The following is not really important, but I'd say it is interesting ;-) A genetic word is always made-up of three letters (triplets/codons). There are 4 different letters , which means the genetic dictionary contains only 64 words. There is 1 word that says where a sequence starts, 3 words that say where it ends and each of the remaining 60 words will be translated into a specific amino acid in a polypeptide chain. So, my thinking was, that a repeair sequence will always be one or more words (triplets/codons) and thus this specific scenario with AAA and AT as a repair sequence should not occur. Also there is no test like this, so it should not be a problem.
OK, I removed the requirement to check for invalid input and adapted test 6 accordingly.
